UEKt0GlOhWSSKL57wi8URg.text: Amidst the din, clubs, and turquoise encrusted kitsch of Old Town Scottsdale is tucked away a quiet enclave- an oasis if you will- of exceptional farm fresh cuisine.   The menu is simple, the ingredients fresh and local, and the execution is impeccable.  Our waiter was engaging and knowledgeable.  The stuffed Hatch chiles a perfect blend of spicy sweetness from the pepper and the tartness of the goat cheese.  The fish was moist and flaky and, when accompanied by some figs, became a pleasant surprise.

kEqTgnwWJ0P_DDjNBc6QEw.text: Our big gay anniversary dinner knocked our vegetarian socks off. We showed up early for our reservation - our bad - so they gave us some champagne while we waited! Every dish was amazing and our server was kind and attentive. Beautiful presentation and charming interior. Thanks FnB!

WVa7VA1CBDBZKxovdAvq1w.text: What a unique experience in Scottsdale compared to the more "chain restaurants". We treated friends to an evening out here and literally ordered everything off of the fall menu. The chickpeas and the kale falafel were top favorites along with the pork shoulder (wow)! We split two desserts and were full but not overly stuffed (which is how I prefer it). Service was relaxed and chill which was perfect for our mode.

kITLNlr-QuU2lFBvlYSMgg.text: This restaurant is trying so hard to be inventive that the food is absurd. The flavors and presentation clash. It's almost an expensive comedy....and the joke is on you.  There are sweet notes to everything.  Seriously...If the food should be savory or salty let it have a different taste then sugar sweet everything.  Obscure ingredients that sound interesting on the menu but contrast the underlying flavor of the ingredients. The service is ridiculously haute. Tattooed 20 something's pretending to be connoisseurs with an attitude.  The prices are exceptionally high for the servings. To their favor... the ingredients are fresh and surely cost more...but not that much more than similar high end restaurants with the same costs. The wait times are long and seating is uncomfortable with a sense of being rushed. Skip this place... it is truly not worth it. Unless being with sheeple makes a fun night out.

Dgb-V77B5CsSv9RXSiH1Sg.text: I thoroughly enjoyed dinner at FnB. The service was prompt and friendly -- I was welcomed and offered a table immediately. Waited for my friend and they brought Pellegrino when I asked for sparkling H20. We split the Jerusalem artichokes (with caramelized onions and feta) as an appetizer and these were fantastic. I then had the asparagus with egg and my friend had the gulyash -- both super tasty and generous size. We ordered a bottle of Corsican Vermentino which was lovely --they have a surprisingly creative wine menu.   All in all a super satisfying meal!

vcuvsLqiW5OTXabhyIcdSw.text: I was impressed by the wine selection, especially what they offer from this region, I had a delicious white from Willcox AZ. The mixed drinks looked nice as well. The staff were welcoming and our server took time to go over everything and answer questions.   I wasn't impressed with the interior decor, it looked outdated. We sat outside and felt comfortable. The dishes we ordered were the falafel app, asparagus and broccoli veggie dishes, and the pasta with carrot sauce main dish. The falafel and asparagus dishes were fantastic, the flavors were interesting and rich. The other two dishes were terrible. The broccoli was basically just burnt, it had yogurt type sauce and grapefruit slices as well. It didn't have a lot of flavor. The pasta dish was weird, I kind of liked the sauce, but it didn't match with the pasta or something. It was unfulfilling. We should have read reviews more closely before going so we could have chosen wiser!

RF_KpSmeUv21AHfIYKY3Fw.text: Very good experience. Attentive server, friendly atmosphere. Well curated menu.  Starters- watermelon and shrimp salad: Tasty, refreshing, well seasoned  Heirloom tomatoes: very fresh, under-salted, nice presentation  Side- zucchini with squash: bland but the zucchini was cooked nicely. Would not order again Main- Pork Chop: fantastic! Perfectly cooked and seasoned. Delicious salad below of corn, peaches, almonds, very tasty.  Overall, would definitely come back for the pork entree.

TtQCNIGVintofJFsiUGBKg.text: How does this place have so many good reviews?   It took 45 minutes for pasta, with no meat, just some heirloom tomatoes, mozzarella and a 'sauce'. There was no flavor to the food at all. We were so let down, the food tasted like it came out of a barilla box.   The hostess told us that there would be a free dessert or champagne in celebration of our anniversary, which didn't happen.   Potatoes and zucchini were fine, but certainly below our expectations, given all the hype and accolade.   Add 2 cocktails and our bill was north of $90.   We literally walked across the street to get dessert and save ourselves having to wait for an inattentive staff to bring out ice cream from Sweet Republic, and berries. K. Thanks.

y9BjxXrBqes3gB102Uv9LA.text: Bumping it up to five stars after this weekend's visit. We tried a bunch of dishes and every single one was delish. Menu changes often with lots of veg and fish options. Love!

photos.caption: Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. Oct 2017 menu- everything delish!

s_Gd7GW-Z_4bPE2LuCCRZg.text: I was to told this place is crazy amazing. Like most farm to table and seasonal menus you expect the flavors of the food to meld together and the menu items to be complimentary of each other. This is not the case. Nothing goes together. The food is just ok and not worth the money. We started off with the ricotta cheese and egg plant dish which was terrible. Texture and taste wrong wrong wrong. Then we had the fried chicken liver which was probably the best thing we ordered but again it was just ok. Next they brought out the corn, sea bass, and mozzarella bacon pasta. I love sea bass and I had one bite and couldnt get myself to eat anymore. My daughter however loved i but husband didnt care for it.  The corn was alright and pasta just ok. The reason I am giving this place 3 stars is not for the food ( because the food is 2 star max) it's for the service and ambiance of the restaurant. They played classic jazz which is great and the lighting and set up of the restaurant is comfortable and inviting. Again it was the 2019 summer seasonal menu maybe they just got it all wrong this season.

B2p27YRdYWrJ-OeS4BngiA.text: I was so glad everyone in our group was happy to use  the shared dish approach so we had an opportunity to try a lot more dishes.   We ordered a lot of food!    I thought the vegetable dishes were outstanding.  Everyone really enjoyed the meal.   Tables are fairly close together and the space itself is small.   The service was good.

photos.caption: Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. Veggie dishes were excellent

hqjFRIxV4dJcUG9czvYs7w.text: Wow what an awesome find and a rare gem in a sea of "themed" resto's in Scottsdale. Food here is noticeably fresh, creative and delicious. A varied changing menu is always a sign for me of a talented creative kitchen. We commented many times during the meal how we appreciated the talent in the kitchen! I don't know if commenting on the specific dishes is relevant because the likelihood of them being on the menu in the future is low but the Takeaway of this review simply is that you can't go wrong here, and if you want fresh delicious creative food this is your spot. Also our waiter and service throughout the evening was outstanding! Actual rating is 4.5 stars

4mqIwPEUmGJLOC__A1JnfA.text: This place can give you the best flavors, like the collard greens appetizer.  You can also get an entree that leaves you wandering where the taste comes from, like the braised chicken dish.  Not a bad flavor, but distinctive.  So, I recommend ordering some small plates rather than committing to one large plate.

photos.caption: Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. Pasta with cheese and crispy prosciutto

RCbHQCytTqob8kMF3-ILDw.text: Great, as always.  We particularly loved the Sea Bass and the shrimp with yellow watermelon on the summer menu.  This is maybe the most consistent, high-quality restaurant in the Valley.  We are only patrons about once a year, but we've been coming since before the move to their current location.  It's truly remarkable how consistent and delicious each of our visits have been.  This place is a Valley treasure.  And don't forget to order the butterscotch pudding for dessert!

88jJqlljg5Ud7q8B7e6jYA.text: Great innovative menu and wonderful food and AZ wine were the highlights.   So noisy we could not even hear the waiter or carry on a conversation.  i will never return for indoor seating, except maybe the bar.  I will definitely return when weather is cooler and we can sit outside

LLShPmj5HLGMomdJBBw2rQ.text: Nice location in old town Scottsdale. Very good wine and drink menu. Service was good. It pretty much ends there.  Appetizers / corn salad very good.  Tomato good.  Some bread with dip was inedible - can't remember name.    Had a chicken entree that was gross. Very little meat. Had claws on the plate that were completely unappealing .  See picture.  Cod entree was ok but cover with sauce and veggies etc... which masked the fish  Did not even consider dessert - won't be back

photos.caption: Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States

yuqdc8DcRNbjMPSuKYGNUg.text: The flavors were really great here! I haven't decided how I feel about canned wine as a premium option. I do appreciate the local commitment. The menu is seasonal so no point highlighting the specific dishes but the food overall was enjoyable!

EjAO1F_myKZZiGdblKPnFQ.text: We came to FnB for dinner as a large group on a Wednesday night. The place was busy but not completely packed. I liked the setup of the place - the different dining rooms helped to give a more private feel and keep the noise levels lower.   The food was fantastic. The hardcore carnivores and picky vegan/vegetarians all found multiple dishes that they enjoyed and wanted to come back for. We ordered family style so that we could try pretty much the entire menu. My favorites were the grilled peaches and corn, halibut entree, and the vegan eggplant tart.   While we did not venture into the extensive wine menu, we did have cocktails (they had four options on the menu). My negronis were strong and expertly made, a perfect pairing to the different dishes we ordered. I would definitely come back again.

XqvaS4fupLZQNiETmxlygA.text: This place is phenomenal I would go again and again! The food is unique, and it is great for sharing! The staff is extremely friendly and the atmosphere is positive. It is a small place so I would recommend making a reservation first. I cant say enough about this place. If I could I would marry it..

89HTp1KpEmbOAWv6KumW3Q.text: Loved it!  Really original.  Wasn't sure after looking over the menu but everything smelled good and tasted even better.  Even my husband, who eats out for work several times a week, was impressed.

IefIT2to3DfR3LPt0hgw7g.text: We booked a reservation here in advance from hearing all the hoopla about it. We were very excited to eat here. The service was wonderful, attentive, knowledgeable and professional. The food however really did not live up to what had read about it. The leek dish was good, but not great. The mozzarella was not a good choice of cheese on it. It seemed clumsy on a dish with such potential. We then had the scallops which were okay. They were lacking in overall flavor, though the scallops themselves were cooked perfectly. The pasta dish was a disaster. Our waiter made a big deal about the pasta being imported from Italy but it was poorly executed. It was like chewing on a gum ball. The crab in the dish seemed frozen and did not have a good flavor or consistency. The sauce on the pasta was soupy. We mentioned our disappointment of the dish to the waiter. He was gracious and took the dish off the bill which we did not expect or want.   So to recap, service great, food not so much.

o1jLYgJn3tlmSdq5jffrBQ.text: Wonderful waiter, great local food.  Love this place.  Will definiately return for more.

kKs0fvVl_KJlwEe2CVIZ4A.text: 4 stars for Scottsdale, maybe 3.5 for LA.    Another key comment, this is not a Gastropub.  Not sure who initially qualified this restaurant as such, but my definition of a Gastropub is a location which serves gourmet-ish, comfort, casual, beer-friendly food with an extensive selection of craft beers and select liquors in a Euro-type setting..  This beer list is comprised of 3-4 beers and not sure any of them are on tap.  Also, there is really nothing "pub" about the layout of this restaurant.   The central kitchen design won me over with the open-flame grill surrounded by bar seating in full view and participation of the women-only chefs creating fresh, simple yet uber-flavorful, seasonal dishes.    We walked in around 9ish on a Saturday night to have our pick of "counter" seating.  The kitchen is literally the size of a small bar area with an open flame grill, salamander and a couple of burners on the back side. I can't imagine how the chefs can operate in this space, but i suppose that prep work is the key.  The menu is small (again, small kitchen) and based mostly on small plates and about 3-4 main dishes.  We ordered the shishito peppers with tahini and black sesame, the beet, watermelon and feta salad, corn on the cob with parmesan and mint and the pasta and pancetta dish along with the indian-inspired halibut with yogurt, basmati rice and cucumber.  The wine list is strictly Arizona wines, which I honestly didn't even know Arizona could produce wines.    So, the low down....  I can honestly say i don't like beets.  It annoys me that i don't, and so every once in a while i try something with beets just  to make sure that I'm not missing out.  The beet-watermelon salad was delicious.  I can't say that i now love beets, but i can say that the balance between the earthiness of the beets and freshness of the watermelon and creaminess of the feta made the dish the best beet dish I've ever had.  It was also complete with some crunchy curry-garlic-herb bits that were charred in the oven.  Ok, now i'm scared since i just wrote a novel about a dish that i usually don't like. Shishito peppers.... unreal.  Tobin downed about 15 of them in 2 minutes.  They were placed on a base of tahini and sesame oil and were charred to still green perfection.  We scooped up every last pepper and wanted more.  Corn on the cob with parmesan and mint, i would have never guessed that those ingredients would work, but they did and I'm excited for Tobin to replicate at home.  And now the slight disappointment came from the main dishes.  The pasta dish was talked up by our host and it was really just another tasty pasta dish.  Pasta was cooked nicely, tomato flavor was good but i didn't taste the richness that was expected from the pancetta.  The Halibut was nice, but maybe too delicate in contrast to our starters.  Now my one complaint... I was served a nice Syrah blend at first and as i finished my first glass with the starters, was not offered another glass (while of course, Tobin was brought a nice Sangiovese blend after his  sub-par first glass of Syrah).  Instead, the server, picked up my glass and no one was at our table to check in until after we had finished our mains.  The servers and staff seemed to be very occupied with a fellow (cute girl) foodie/critic/industry insider sitting next to us, and we got an unfortunate cold shoulder.  That's what always makes me sad about service, I can usually over-order on wine and other beverages, but somehow they don't see that and lose out on additional sales.  I guess it's always a blessing for me seeing as I save a hangover the next morning and have a few extra bucks in my bank account.  Overall, i would recommend this place for anyone visiting Scottsdale and wants a quality, non-cheesy dinner atmosphere.  I would return next time i visit and hope to try more satisfying dishes and hopefully more than one glass of wine.

pI2zTCpTaiWxVxDYDBzK2Q.text: Food was so yummy! We are definitely going back! From the entrees to dessert, every dish was delicious. Okra was cooked and seasoned so well!

1PT-yfpAsYdrzqTzBMUujw.text: I was visiting a friend in Scottsdale and was yelping my way around tryin' to figure out where to eat. Somehow I found this place. At the last minute they were able to give us a reservation for dinner... We ended up being seated in the owner's section. He started off the evening by letting us know that he didn't recognize us... when we explained it was because we were New Yorkers... and it was our first time, he aimed to impress! Local wine, a carefully plotted menu, and a free dessert... even after we were stuffed... For a couple of New Yorkers who moved west, the staff at FnB definitely did the East Coast proud in a dainty little bistro in the wild, wild west. After hours, by the way, on the weekends, they turn on some different music... and have an alternate menu. Very awesome spot.

TigPdIala94irW_LAWnLXQ.text: What a great place!  The food was beyond fresh and so flavorful.  We sat at the bar and watched the 3 chefs create the fantastic food right before us.  The pork chop was amazing served with fresh peaches and corn and the special squash blossom appetizer was delicious.  Great service in a quaint atmosphere!

LxDOIarp0d8LZ96E1w22Bg.text: One of our favorite places in the Valley! The braised leeks are unlike anything you are goi g to get anywhere. Just order them and thank me later. The grilled broccoli with Meyer lemon breadcrumbs was also a huge hit! The side dishes alone a good enough to warrant a visit!

vyNeQX217n7nMTwGXKwQUQ.text: Seeing so many good reviews I was curious to try.  The kitchen is in the middle of the restaurant and I sat at the bar over looking it.  It's always interesting to see the chefs in action.  The server was extra friendly.  The atmosphere was hip.  And the food was creative and delicious.  Each dish better than the next.  FnB did not disappoint.

j3pPFTYCl_YByTXwKnXaUA.text: Truly a perfect place......small plates, amazing food, good for the environment. We talked to the lady chef, rather than just chef, during the meal. She shops for fresh ingredients at local markets during the day. That is why the menu changes almost nightly. We loved it and it is good for you too. Not a better place in Scotsdale.

tZ3h_1AMvLWjm3HlULIoDg.text: This place is a hidden little jewel that apparently only locals know about. Since I am now a "local" I know too. Amazing is the only word I can think of. All fresh ingredient and made with love. I had the house made Margarita with no refined sugar at all. Just Tequila and fresh citrus. That's it! Then leeks with fresh mozzarella, bread crumbs and egg on top. Also rock shrimp, razor clams and cheese plate. Wow!  So European and yummy.

__yFDnw5aUU914e3AycGFQ.text: Went there on  a quite Sunday night, shared a different number of appetizers, not very impressed with the execution. It was just ok, i guess i was expecting a lot better considering the good reviews and the high prices.

TBggC4ADPRZr-9e8kEK77Q.text: This is definitely one of the best restaurants in Arizona. FnB has incredible ingredients and the food is prepared perfectly. I definitely tried a lot of things I wouldn't normally see on menus in Scottsdale and loved everything.  I go frequently and the food, service, and ambiance has been perfect every time.

crM5WlPkcIwtlPeF0n5hzA.text: This was the highlight of my business trip to Phoenix.  Everything I had was excellent, and the service is second to none.  I fly back just to eat here.

TX5tdaZ8KwqqbSZxXfBt5A.text: This restaurant, and I shudder a bit to call it that because what we're talking about here is a complete and total gastronomic experience, is a must if you are ever in the Scottsdale area. The food is all local, organic and sustainable when possible even down to the wine list which is replete with local selections. What they do with what they procure is just astonishing. From the moment you walk in the door, you are welcomed and made to feel at home and they are genuinely grateful that you have decided to dine there. In the center of the small room is a lovely wrap around counter where you can watch an open kitchen. The three chefs mingle in elegant dance of culinary construction that recalls Joel Robuchon's L'Atelier in Las Vegas (though considerably less expensive). The menu is sparse with 3 or 4 offerings in each category but descriptions that cause me to want to order everything. Rock Shrimp with Jalapeno tartar is a standard. When I asked my local friends if they would like to share a plate, they replied "no, they were getting their own!" The Jidori chicken was simply the best tasting, juicy and succulent poultry preparation I have ever had. Hands down. I did not get the butterscotch pudding for dessert and that is my one regret. I had a taste and all I can say is, "Bradley Ogden, beware!!" The cowboy style creme brulee, with the sugar top burned in with a branding iron was fantastic. The custard was hinted  with lavender, honey and local fruits. I wanted to chew the remaining bits of burned sugar off the ramekin with my teeth (propriety notwithstanding, I managed to behave). The server acted like he was the owner in a good way, kind, gentle, friendly and knowledgeable about the menu and the wines. The owner came up to chat a few times but mostly was manning his station, ensuring quality control. The gestalt of the experience was just stunning. I will return again and again.

DlWFJmiyC9rdALkL0rEq0Q.text: We had such an amazing meal at this place!  Everything was so fresh and delicious.  We sat at the bar and was able to watch the chefs do their thing.  It was really cool.  Our server was also amazing!  Extremely knowledgeable.  Made great suggestions!  Everything thing that we tried was great and I am still dreaming about the butterscotch pudding :)

V8lMNTvl_hP4380e5p3lwQ.text: I guess my experience was not as great as most. The service was great and the atmosphere was fantastic... maybe it was my dinner selection? Had the pasta: was a a bit dry and made me feel a little queasy after.   Would definitely go back for wine and drinks though!

oww9cOveJ7fZVa8etx8JYw.text: FnB is basically the reason my husband and I come to Scottsdale from Seattle. We visited again in April and were not disappointed. We had a couple of apps, all delicious, the the many pickled eggs was a standout. I had great lamb chops and my husband had some unbelievable pasta with chicken liver and spring peas and some other magical stuff.  We each started with a martini and progressed to tap wine. This place actually makes me wish I had a bigger stomach.

E4JXtXsEJREaOjnXqR5YuQ.text: I have been to FnB three times since it opened and each experience has been great!  Food is fanatstic - propers to Charlene and Pavle! This is a restaurant not to be missed! From hand-crafted cocktails to entrees that sing and vegetables that every kid in America should eat -- what is not to like?!   Also, the late night (10 p.m.) daily dinner special will not disappoint!

4Eyh66md6CkH7xWXkfthYA.text: Why can't this be right around the corner from my house? Makes me want to move to old town Scottsdale. Delicious ingredients, creative combinations, and super fresh food. Always a treat.

photos.caption: Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. The best salad of my life.
Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. Salt cod
Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. Parker&#39;s Ham.

zkDIFJ2vesYnyas6nv8lkA.text: This was a great restaurant, real attempt at seasonal and local food.  We are all are meat eaters, but the veg looked so good we focused on that and ordered a bunch of appetizers.  The food was excellent, really top draw.  Cocktails were fun and wine selection was good.  Seemed all pretty reasonable price. My only reason I am not giving a five star is I though the host was a little rude to us.

9Rp_5Rm4Pol1A1h8LN7nKg.text: The food at FnB is nothing short of excellent! Went with a large group and ordered almost the entire menu to share. Everyone in our party was raving about one Item or another. I'm not a fan of okra but I must admit their preperation was pretty delicious.     Had our server been a touch more attentive and slightly less condescending I would have given 5 stars. But it was nothing that would prevent me from recommending FnB or returning when I'm in the area

vV6gHlCukLEJ09ZJOJqJjA.text: Dinner was fantastic! Everything we ate was wonderful! I went with a party of 5 and we got 3 appetizers, 2 veggies and 3 entrees. It was a perfect amount of food and everyone raved about the taste. Steak with chimichurri and tuna poke were among the crowd favorites. The menu changes a lot so I am sure whenever you go anything you get will be good. Staff was very friendly as well and recommended a bottle of wine for the table. Definitely recommend and will go back the next time in Phoenix!

XPoMUKNslWZMZ-IR-GvuIA.text: Some really outstanding flavors and experimental cuisine here. The menu changes frequently so don't bother trying to look at the one on their site. That part is a bit frustrating.  Keep in mind entrees for dinner run $25-35 but the appetizers are all in the $12-15 range. We tend to just order the apps and get a few of them. They are usually quite excellent and they do great things with veggies and creams.  The only downside for us is the unnecessarily pretentious Tattoos man that waits on everyone. Every question you ask him, you will be made to feel like an idiot. He truly thinks you should just shut up and order. I believe his name was Pavle.  I'd probably give this place more stars but the entire table agreed we just weren't liking the main persons attitude so they can take our 2 stars and our $200 and suck it. Suck it hard. Maybe if they get rid of Mr Knowitall we will be back.

IfqQ53_c1P312Zbch6BMPA.text: Lamb rib let appetizer was delicious! The carrot dish was unreal! how good can carrots be you ask? Well I'm not a vegetarian but this dish would persuade me. A perfect place for unique flavors but you don't walk away feeling sickly full. It's a pleasant full feeling.

k-Ub3U-5ZxLEOQHGk6Ftfg.text: My gf's and I came here for our last night of a bachelorette party. There were 12 of us and we all agreed that this was one of the best meals we've ever had. We ordered a family style set menu. The different dishes, flavors, presentation...everything, was AMAZING! I rarely write reviews but had to for this restaurant. Oh and the staff were so friendly and attentive.

yOytnlSYVlpPErpm7dbtyg.text: This is my favorite AZ restaurant.  I love the small space, and the staff is so kind and friendly.  The best thing about FnB is the vegetables -- anyone can cook a good steak (and their skirt steak is indeed delicious!), but Charleen can make you weep over a plate of leeks. I also really appreciate all they do to promote AZ wine, which is so good and so underrated.

Hi7YaeeDTD96csCc9erfsg.text: FbB 4theWIN!!!! It's small, local, delectable deliciousness. With a rotating menu (I believe it changes daily) do NOT come in expecting Cheesecake Factory style encyclopedia menu. You literally might have 4-5 things to choose from.... But those "things" will be some of the best bites of food you've ever put in your mouth. And don't forget to check out their little store where you can purchase fruits /veggies / bread/wine.

photos.caption: Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. I don&#39;t remember what this was, but it doesn&#39;t matter... Because it won&#39;t be there when you go, lol.

EjKqxs2DTsSclWlDbaGA7Q.text: Interesting menu and top notch service make this a restaurant worth going to. Tip move past the local wine list and ask for the plan B wine list.

JjSYMb5NFUZy1MounIU4sQ.text: This place is amazing!! All the dishes are unique; from all parts of the world...Hungary, the Middle East, Russia, Germany. So much creativity, and so much flavor! Our waiter was amazing!! He was so knowledgeable, and so down to earth. He really made the evening fun! The rest of the staff is incredibly friendly and attentive. While people did come in jeans and a T-shirt, it really is a place where you should dress nicer (i.e. polo/blouse/nice jeans, etc). Great for a date night or for foodies. Can't recommend this place high enough! Oh, and plan ahead; I had to book our reservation days in advance...and the only spot I could get was 5pm. But it is well worth it!!

6ki5bm7dzb1MQMjwJlex-w.text: As we arrived at FnB we immediately felt right at home. There was a faint smell of toasted marshmallows in the air and the hustle and bustle of Chef Charlene Badman's small open kitchen felt like being at mom's. The warm glow of owner/manager Pavle Milic's face fortified the welcome feeling.  Short for Food and Beverage, FnB seems to have everything aligned for culinary greatness. With food and service worthy of a long-established restaurant, you'd be surprised that FnB has been open only a few months.  Located in Old Town Scottsdale, the space formerly housed the famed Sea Saw. The bar surrounds the small open kitchen, with views of Badman and Sous Chef Sacha Levine working their magic. Or, if romance is in the air, opt for a table for two. FnB is cozy and intimate.  Farm fresh, seasonal and comforting describe Badman's creative and fun menu. Even something as simple as Citrus Marinated Olives ($4) just tastes better with a touch of orange peel.  The menu is not large, with only a handful of nibbles, appetizers, sides and entrees. On one visit, our knowledgeable waiter didn't even bat an eye when we ordered just about everything on the menu.  Lightly dusted in semolina flour then flash fried, each crustacean of the Crispy Rock Shrimp and Jalapeno Tartar ($9) has a nice feathery crunch. Fried Green Tomatoes with Green Goddess Dressing and Feta ($11) combines classic components, yet brings something new and balanced to the table.  Braised Leeks, Mozzarella, Mustard Bread Crumbs and a Fried Egg ($13) are as simple as they sound, but tastier than you'd imagine. This is the beauty of Badman's cooking: farm-fresh produce prepared with love and attention.  Since it is based on seasonal bounties, the menu is always changing, so don't be surprised when your favorite dish is no longer available. During several visits I had the opportunity to try something new each time.  Try not to fall in love with the pasta offering -- on one visit the pasta was a Garganelli and other times it was Strozzapreti ($19). Both were perfect, cooked al dente and served with local veggies.  Blue Nose Bass, Snap Peas, Hazelnuts and Citrus Sauce ($21) was fresh and light, yet meaty and satisfying.  Roast Jidori Chicken ($20) sounds like a cooking preparation, so I was surprised that it's actually a breed of Japanese chicken. Smaller than your standard chicken, it's amazingly flavorful and juicy. As one of my dining mates put it, "It tastes how chicken used to taste." Each succulent bite reminded me of how simple ingredients in expert hands can be so fulfilling.  Grilled Broccoli, Meyer Lemon Aioli and Crispy Onion ($6) is one of the sides. The smokiness of the slight char on the broccoli is alluring and adds an exotic dimension to something that would otherwise be ordinary.  Badman's desserts are handled with as much love and care as the rest of our experience, which made them all the sweeter. Topped with whipped cream and finished with a grating of nutmeg, each joyous spoonful of the Butterscotch Pudding ($7) brought comfort and delight.   Looking into the kitchen, I could see plumes of smoke in the air as a ramekin filled with Mint Chocolate Creme Brulee ($7) was getting seared with an iron.  It all made sense as burning sugar filled the air, like roasting marshmallows at a campfire. It's one of those things you long to come back to -- home.

h4eTHXeXOBe-3LOZDG3lXg.text: First and foremost - the food was delicious... very good and creative dishes that are well planned and perfectly portioned.   Chef did a great job!   BUT... as important as the food is - the service has to match especially for an expensive restaurant like this.  Our server was terrible... he was inattentive - did not check back in with us, did not fill up our glasses of wine, gave a nasty look to our guest who changed their order less than 30 seconds after ordering, forgot to put part of our order in, and never once asked how the food was.    There are lots of great restaurants in Scottsdale... and all of them have better service.  Hopefully they can get their act together since their restaurant is hard to find as it is buried in the back of a small building and they probably rely a lot upon word of mouth.

BYL9LVs_kB5FZexPnP17tQ.text: This place is a gem. We usually go for lunch, because we find dinner to be too expensive unless there is a special occasion. We order everything off the menu for lunch and share. All the salads are always very good; same thing for the veg dish. There have been a few pickled dishes that were truly amazing. The sandwich course is a hit-miss for me. Sometimes, its good. Sometimes, I could pass.  I could never pass dessert. Caramel and whipped cream. Who can pass that up?

OoLUrwmc1DZBinBxXLQVDQ.text: Visiting from SF FnB Best meal we had in Scottsdale ... inventive ..  you can taste the freshness of the ingredients .. they seem proud of what they are doing .. & they have a right to be.

YXj4aUnCC73NLGaLNf8tGA.text: 2nd visit, 5 months apart. Very good, both times.  Very good cocktails and local wines.  We dined tapas style.  Peruvian Chicken Spring Rolls, Blood Orange & Roasted Beet Salad,  Mussels, Braised Baby Leeks,  Spicy Grilled Broccoli, Roasted Cauliflower...  Dessert was Blood Orange Cake w/ Pistachio Ice Cream.  All the plates were well presented and delicious.  Great service in a very comfortable atmosphere.

3iuPxhMl_UCI2qmTdHaUBQ.text: * FARM TO TABLE GEM in Downtown Scottsdale!!! *  friendly staff, nice atmosphere, flavorful plates.  FnB stands for Food and Beverage.  farm to table restaurant with local ingredients.  i did not take a picture of our actual menu since i figured it would be online...oops.  menu changes with what's fresh and in season. (and i left my phone in the hotel room on the charger, so i didn't take photos either that night...shame on me.)   beet salad - different colors of beets, mixed greens, wheat berry, lightly dressed in a viniagrette  asparagus with polenta cakes - i love polenta cakes. these were triangular in shape.  cauliflower dish - this one tasted like a healthy meatball marinara dish!! IT WAS THE MOST DELICIOUS CAULIFLOWER dish i've ever had.  cauliflower, marinara sauce, fennel sausage.  there was a bit of spiciness in it. Mmm...kudos to the chef!!  she's amazing.  butterscotch pudding - good balance of salty sweet flavors. butterscotch pudding topped with whipped cream and nutmeg  chocolate whiskey cake with ice cream - should've stopped at one dessert but decided to indulge since we were on vacay. enjoyed everything else, so figured...why not? =)  moist, round chocolate cake drizzled with a whiskey chocolate syrup. a scoop of vanilla ice cream complimented it well (though i thought the vanilla ice cream they used was too sweet)  they have a simple menu. there is one for lunch (no brunch), dinner, and late night. dinner is from 5-10pm. late night is after 10 (until midnight).  for the late night menu all wine is half off.  EAT, DRINK, and BE MERRY!!!

ez8Pm26j6DsqJhyLfbEwBQ.text: Horrible restaurant. Crappy service! Rude servers. As we sat down the server decided we are not allowed to order anything. He would decide what we should all eat & drink. Some of us wanted to look at the menu but he took it away before we could look. Then he bought out some crap wine & even worst food. Quote "I don't have time to make cocktails so I suggest you all have wine", "this is my favourite dish". Never asked what we wanted. He insisted we only eat what he wanted to serve. When you are a paying customer you expect go have some choice.

uoYnXElswb2V55IiUgQwQg.text: The chef does his/her job in delivering unique and well put together dishes.  The service is good but not to the level they seem to want the restaurant to reach.  Simple things like bringing bread and olive oil right away so we don't need to enjoy our sparkling wine "dry".  Waiter seemed preoccupied with answering the phone while taking our order.  Waiter seemed rushed to serve our sparkling wine to the point of overfilling our glasses.

AUPJFn7fbtmRwlZDyeuzAQ.text: 1/30/10  Came in for dinner.  My second time at this location (the first was when it was the newly-transferred Digestif during Yelp Eats Week).  What a great transformation from a dark, smoky venue to a warmer, much-more inviting space- thanks to those b/w and prismatic floor tiles!  My EXCELLENT meal consisted of table bread and basil olive oil; the marvelous and perfectly cooked flat-iron steak, medium to medium-rare (cauliflower, golden raisin salsa verde); and the stupefyingly-addiciting puff pastry Chef Charleen created that night w/ AZ pecans, vanilla ice cream, and Wild Turkey caramel sauce (corn-free!!).  I had to muster up all of my willpower to sock-away half of the steak (the raisin salsa verde made this dish a winner!) for my Mom to try at home (she's hard-to-please, but LOVED the leftovers), so that I could demolish the pastry creation :)  [I just recently found out I'm allergic to pecans, but y'know, this dish is so good, I'd definitely keep it in mind on my next visit when considering my dessert options!]  While still enjoying in the aftermath of such a wonderful meal, I was pleasantly surprised to find that my table ticket arrived w/ a small chunk of homemade toffee crunch.  However, this lovely-looking sweet contained an allergen or two, so Charleen switched it w/ a two-bite chocolate chocolate chip cookie.  What a sweet way to wish me good night!  Yelp Eats/Restaurant Week, where are you??

8K07q8n_hhfh90w3EJgHig.text: Second time at FnB at both times were soooo good. Our strategy is to order several of the non-entrees so we can try as many different dishes as possible.   Not much else I can say.. the food is amazing. Period.  It does get loud it is inside when busy. There's fabric hanging on the high ceilings but it's still pretty loud.

RNBcum5346Sb9po1wb2pUQ.text: This is probably not fair because we didn't eat there.  I HATE crowded noisy places.   I specifically asked on my reservation if we could not be seated in a place where we could hear each other without shouting to let me know and we would cancel.  We arrived,  place is deafening,  tables stacked on top of each other.   There was a quieter room but told it wasn't available     No valet service.   Park in crappy garage and walk on broken pavement to get there.  No thanks.  I will continue to go to cafe Monarch or sel.

jA96g0BuTtwZ9VKkCOpfIA.text: I am so disappointed in my experience at FnB. It started off poorly with the service. It took about 5 minutes for a waiter to come over and acknowledge us (which should never be the case). After asking for another minute to look at drinks, it took about another 5 minutes to order drinks (thus, we ordered food at the same time). After ordering, everything was fine. All the servers were engaged in a timely manner with dishes, refills, etc.   The food is truly the disappointment. As I sit here writing, I am trying to recall the good dishes we had, but I can't remember them. I know we ordered four dishes, but I only remember two... because they were bad.   One dish was the Nashville HOT Chicken Livers. For some, this may sound disgusting. I like chicken livers. I also love hot chicken, but OMG it was HOT. It was too hot where you couldn't taste any flavor. It was so hot it caused us to chug multiple glasses of water. One server noticed this and as she filled our water told us how much she loved hot food, but won't even eat this dish. Yes, it says HOT on the menu which should tell someone it is hot, but my fiance has had Nashville hot chicken (e.g. Hattie B's) and this was too hot. Moreover, the constant chugging of water completely destroyed our appetite.    The other dish that was a disaster was the Shishito peppers. Personally, I feel Shishito peppers are overdone like how kale eventually was overdone, but they are good. You fry them up and season them.  Simple. We decided to try their version because it was different. It was mixed with potatoes and an Aioli sauce. Not to be mean, but it was horrible. Basically, someone dumped a poorly flavored mayonnaise on the plate and poured the veg on top. We had one bite each and were done with the dish and dinner.   I know they can change up the menu, which I love, but unfortunately these two dishes missed the mark.   Another thing that truly irked me - I love to ask servers their favorite dishes. They know best! Nothing bothers me more then when they say everything on the menu is great! Well, I experienced a worse answer. The server said he doesn't ever suggest his favorites. He wants the kitchen to speak for itself. Well, based on the kitchen that night I would have really appreciated his favorites.

qpjNrpKXv0ythWW1ywt_6A.text: We were in town and decided to make a reservation (they are necessary) at FnB based on personal recommendations, reviews and their James beard award winning chef.  This is a tiny spot, almost feels like you are in a house- off of 5th street in old town. The menu changes each season and we were told by our waitress that all ingredients are local (when they can't be made in house) and organic. The service was outstanding the entire night.  There were three of us and we ordered 2 starters, 2 entrees and 2 desserts. Everything was spaced out perfect and each thing we tried was amazing.  There are a lot of restaurants in old town, but very few quality restaurants. This is hands down the best spot.

XXbHCothtRFookYfu4UheQ.text: Came for an anniversary dinner. Called ahead and was greeted at the door and remembered for gluten allergy.   Excellent service.  Accommodating for allergies.   Recommend the Summer Squash and the Spaghetti Squash.  Enjoyed the halibut, loved the hint of spice with the Poblano pepper.  Enjoyed the peaches with prosciutto, would have loved an extra dash of salt on the peaches.   10/10 recommend. Congratulations to chef for winning James Beard Award!  Well done!

TBWmId_qxnwA7D0U17Czag.text: Charleen Badman chef at FnB was just named Best Chef--Southwest by the James Beard Foundation. We waited two months for a prime time weekend reservation--before the award was announced. On Saturday, we definitely felt like we had the best table in the city.   FnB in located on a courtyard in Old Town. It spans several rooms with the bar to the far left--it's open seating if you don't want to wait two months. We were seated at a table by the window in the right most room. The decor is sparse but bright.  Our strategy for ordering was simple--stick to apps and small plates so we could try as many things as possible. Badman has been called "the veggie whisperer" and well over half the menu is vegetarian. We got the falafel, the grilled asparagus, the celtuce, the spaghetti squash, and the butterscotch pudding.   The polenta under the asparagus was one of the best things I've ever eaten. It was creamy with just a little crunch on the edges. The richness of the egg yolk soaked in and paired perfectly with the asparagus. It was wonderfully elevated comfort food. The spaghetti squash was our other favorite. The tomatoes were tangy and perfect with the sweetness of the squash. Then there was the butterscotch pudding--it was about half whipped cream and half very sweet pudding put it all had about the same texture. It was divine.  FnB was worth the wait and Badman has definitely earned her laurels.

CTvivE-bovjJzyZLTVZxqw.text: Ok. I have to be honest. At the end of the day we were like "meh".  I don't know. May be because when we called for reservations we were told maybe you can sit at the bar. But when we got there (with no reservation) the restaurant was half full and seated right away (which was cool. But why deter us with you won't even get a table).   From what I can remember, our portions were small, flavorless and pricey. Just not impressed.   3 stars for not my cup of tea.

photos.caption: Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. Kitchen working.

6a3W37NWhk8d9DZQ-lYDJQ.text: I went to FnB on a one night stayover business trip.  I was immediately concerned with this place when looking at the menu.  Restaurants that try too hard, especially by combining basic ingredients in new and contrived ways should give anyone pause.  I had the summer squash with ricotta, pepita's and some other pepper that had some fire.  All that would be good, but what came to me was a big sloppy mess on a plate and not very good.  To be good, squash needs to be roasted really well and through, this was undercooked.  I also ordered the Halibut, which had a similar plating strategy-as much as possible piled high with a heavy hand.  Why ruin a perfectly good piece of fish by deep frying it with a heavy batter and mayonnaise slathered all over it?  The last bites of just the fish made me realize that what I liked was the mayonnaise, rice and sesame seeds.  Why do servers feel it necessary to ask how you are liking your dish while taking your first bite and still chewing?  It's incredibly awkward.  Sorry, FnB is just off for this palate.

Ru9bEEAxX8zFwSyTCnkClw.text: FnB Restaurant is a contemporary restaurant located in the arts district of old town scottsdale. They offer a farm focused menu of innovated globally inspired dishes that are meant to be shared, entrees, cocktails and a wine menu that focus on Arizona Wines. Some offerings on the menu you might not be familiar with such as "Farcous" (French Chard Fritter), Celtuce (Obscure stem lettuce), Bagna Cauda (warm hot Italian Dip) and many others but don't worry you server will explain. The menu is broken down into cold sharing plates, warm sharing plates and entrees. The menu showcases vegetables but also offers meat proteins embellish with extraordinary vegetables.  It's always difficult to decide on what to order because they offer so many things that sound delicious. I like to order two - three sharing plates..and at least one dinner for two people but often my husband wants his own dinner and we have the most amazing leftovers to bring home. But I figure I don't go here as often as I want to so I try to make the most of my visit.  Whatever you order they start you off with our best locally made bread called Noble Bread and serve it with High Quality Olive Oil. Tonight we started with the Radish Salad that was made with the freshest fanciest radishes that don't taste sharp like super market radishes. They were dressed in caper anchovy dressing with pumpkin seeds and sweet dates. It was a light and delicious salad.  We also shared the Salmon Gefilte Fish Plate. Everyone out there would love gefilte fish if all of them were made like this. So fresh and mild with a light as a cloud texture with fresh herbs. Also on the plate were pickled beets with a really delicious flavor that I'm not familiar with, pickled eggs, beet horse radish and buttered matzo. It all went together really well.  If you like fish you should get the fish dish because it is always fresh and prepared as well as the finest places in Vegas. Tonight I tried the Mexican Grouper...It was so fresh that it just melted in my mouth. It also was over the top delicious with a bountiful pile of vegetables and fancy herbs. My husband tried the Veal Loin and we shared a sharing plate of Corona Beans....Even the beans were like no other....Really plump and sweet in a broth with bright herbs and flavorful provolone cheese.  Sadly I was way too full to order dessert but I usually do because dessert is always great here. Actually I ordered too much food and I had a large box and a small box to bring home.  The Chef for many years now has been nominated for a James Beard Award and this year (2019) is a Semi Finalist.  The restaurant is small and is usually busy so you need to make a reservation.

xKKVdiKGzNp3c9mLHPfn5A.text: Highly overrated and underwhelming. The "inventive" flavors just did not work for me. We opted for all vegetarian dishes and I am confused as to how this place holds such a high level of prestige. I'm sure the ingredients are all of highest quality so it unfortunate that there was a lack of seasoning/spices/flavor.

0d5hVrk4hiQ2LkVdoA0QOw.text: This is our first time in the restaurant and it definitely surpasses the previous reviews I've read. Service is good and attentive enough but not too overwhelming. It's a quaint place and the atmosphere is very casual and relaxed. You can hear pop music playing in the background but not too loud. My group was having conversations without having to yell at each other. We were a group of six and we were seated comfortably.  They also have an extensive wine list and cocktails.  The food was very tasty and well seasoned. I know now, firsthand, why Chef Charleen Badman won the 2019 James Beard Award. The main dishes were big enough portions that you could share with the table. We ordered for starters: crudite and salad of strawberries. I love the chamoy sauce for the crudite, very interesting pairing. We also tried the grilled summer squash and it's one of our favorites. For the main course we ordered the pasta, chicken, lamb, and the fish dishes (basically one of each) and they did not disappoint!!!   Then, for the dessert we got the old-fashioned butterscotch pudding, butter toasted cornbread with strawberries and strawberry buttermilk ice cream and a rhubarb pie. They're all very tasty but our favorite was the butter toasted cornbread with strawberries. Perfect ending for the meal!   Overall, we will definitely visit the restaurant again when we get a chance. Kudos to Chef Charleen Badman for a job well done for showcasing local products in a very fresh and innovative way.

EPSqJO5PBgDSzztyZiVUCw.text: I visited 3 great restaurants while in Scottsdale, this is the one I would come back to first.   It was truly unique, not pretentious, a bit on the value side of a pricey restaurant town. Most of all, FnB, is oh so different and delicious. Isn't that why we go out, to do something we ourselves could not do better?  The restaurant has 3 rooms it's relatively small with a down market elegance to it.  This will make sense when you show up. The patio is small but a good idea too. The is a quiet place tucked away from the business streets all around you in downtown Scottsdale.  The staff is competent and friendly. We were lucky enough to be there when it was not overfull with patrons. So things worked out perfectly.  Besides the understated elegance the menu takes some time to digest so take your time. It's mostly a fusion restaurant of fine fresh greens and is forward on local goodness. If you are a carnivore and can't stand spending high dollars on greens, then be rest assured there is just enough choice on the menu for that kind of person. Super large parties are probably not going to do all that well here.   FOOD WISE: Enjoy the many blended flavors which is why I nod this place towards 5 stars and not 4. It's the talent and care in the kitchen that is so obvious once you try the amazing food. My favorite dishes were the radish / date starter and the squash. All of it was amazing. If you are True foodie, this will definitely be a special night out.   WINE WISE: It was also the first time I had a GSM from Arizona , and I must say I was impressed. You should try a GSM from Arizona. We tried both of the value choices, I liked the spiciness and finish of the Dos Cabezas just a tad better. Both decent choices at $12/glass. There is a special menu of really top flight bubbly, rose' and other top flight wines if you are feeling the urge to go deep.   Anything on this menu is a splurge, and order up from small to large.  ENJOY!

ZEhEIQneRRxj7ABBd-hFDw.text: Had a great dinner at FnB.  The vegetable options are incredible!  It's not only a vegetarians dream, it's great for anyone that is vegetable friendly and if you don't think you are...you will be after eating here!  Don't get confused though, they do offer protein choices as well; such as chicken, pork and fish.  We were a party of 4 and opted for 4 share dishes and one main.  Loved the kale falafel - not the dried out variety you may be familiar with.  No, no, no - this was moist and delicious, yet crispy on the outside on a yummy sauce.  And they kindly served 4 by request so we could each have one.  Another loved item was their long beans.  Fantastic!  But the dish that took my heart was their pasta with lobster mushrooms in a parmesan broth. OMG!  Other items were pretty good too, but those 3 were my fav's.  The best part of our night was a visit from Pavle to assist us in selecting one of their touted Arizona wines.  They are known for showcasing a great variety of local wines and being from CA wine country, we were eager to try some.  He did a great job at pointing us in the right direction and was more than hospitable, sharing history and restaurant information.  The least fav part of our evening was the extremely loud, boisterous table sitting behind us, making it almost impossible to converse.  In hindsight, we should have asked to be moved as I'm sure they would have been happy to accommodate.  Next time, I will...

870fahFiYl0WFOz3b_hiUg.text: FnB is a hidden gem located in old town Scottsdale. Given the number of kudos for the chef from James Beard and other awards programs, I had to check it out.   The dining room is a bit cramped and the evening we were there, a bit warm. But once the food started to appear, I forgot those things.   This is a vegetable-forward restaurant. But it does serve a variety of proteins if you're not totally into vegetables, like myself.   We started with the Tuscan Kale Falafel, Radishes and Creole Style BBQ Shrimp. The Shrimp was the winner of the first course.   For entrees we ordered the Braised Niman Ranch Pork Shoulder and Dave's Roast Chicken. The Pork Shoulder was amazingly flavorable and tender. Our portion could easily feed two.   Our server Maggie was highly attentive and knows the menu inside and out.

aw293MyDk7T1_BYpbTuW9g.text: Great food, intimate, and superior staff  Was back in PHX for a work trip and a few coworkers and I wanted to hit somewhere great for dinner. We agreed on FnB based on their rep and location.   The restaurant is a cool re-use of spaces off of Old Town Scottsdale. It's close quarters, but they've made the space work and it comes across as intimate versus cramped. Volume wasn't bad and our group could converse and laugh without having to yell at each other, nor overhear the conversations of others.  The food and service are what set FnB apart. We had an extra person join us and squeezed them in. The maitre d' quickly let us know he was able to play some Tetris with reserved parties and re-sat us with a bit more space. Super chill guys and the crew had our settings moved in two minutes flat. Then came the food. Oh, my. That sweet, sweet food.   The pasta with lobster and mushrooms was mad smackin' tasty and I left no trace of it on my plate. Others had the same and loved it. Also popular were the fish, some okra-base side, and a vegetarian dish that I don't recall. everyone was enthuse about their food.  Dessert was marked by a Semifreddo. I'm apparently an uncultured hyena, because I had never heard of this dish. But I ate it all like a beast and know it well, now. As did two others. Something across frozen whipped cream, ice cream, and nuts. Cold, but not so that it chills your mouth. Basically, it's like kissing a sweet cloud chased by a nutty finish.   Definitely. Go.   nom nom nom

photos.caption: Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States

q72gKwonEj35n741hB_imA.text: Quaint little restaurant in old town Scottsdale owned by a Michelin chef. That said, it doesn't make it a Michelin restaurant. The service was fine but not outstanding. The waiter was informative but seemed to forget little details like filling up our waters regularly, splitting the check as requested.   As for the food, it was a mixed reviews from our table. We ordered several appetizers which all agreed was the best part of the meal. The summer salad was excellent, refreshing  and very flavorful. The shishito peppers were also delicious.   The squash side dish and Mexican corn dish (I forget what they are named) were just ok.   Three of us ordered an entree. I had the flounder which was good. My husband had the  pork chop which he felt the meat was prepared well but didn't particularly enjoy how the dish was dressed. Our friend ordered the pasta which was slightly over cooked.   Lastly, we figured we would have dessert and ordered the plum upside down cake and the butterscotch pudding. They were not overly sweet which is good but after a few bites, I was done as I wasn't tempted to have anymore.   Overall the appetizers were 5 stars for us. The sides and entrees were 3 stars. My flounder was a 4.

crgaBVmGL7vi-asKviynlQ.text: I FINALLY made it in to FnB with friends and we had the most wonderful time! We have been dying to try it for so long and can't believe it took us this long to discover the amazingness. The menu is comprised of primarily small plates with a few entree selections as well. It changes regularly based on what is in season, etc. They're very big on supporting local! I love this. I was VERY impressed with the serving sizes of their small plates and they're also willing to adjust sizes based on how many people are in your party.  We had a group of 10 but split our small plates as couples. My husband and I started with their wild Mexican shrimp, tomato juice, serrano, jicama, hominy, avocado, and buttered saltines. It was served cold with 4 giant shrimp and loads of sauce and goodies. It was INCREDIBLE. It tasted just like the authentic shrimp cocktails that I get in Mexico, minus the ocean view. :) Next, we tried their shishito peppers that had a red pepper/romesco type sauce. They were so mild and delicious. Lastly, we split their cold sliced potatoes with eggs and a grain dijon mustard sauce over the top with herbs. LOVED them. However, if you're expecting warm potatoes, not for this one! We ordered entrees as well so 3 small plates + an entree each was a lot of food! We definitely could have stuck with 2 small plates.   For my entree, I ordered their Creekstone Farms ribeye with a pepper relish, fennel, and wheat berries. The flavors were unique and the sauce almost tasted like a vinaigrette. It also isn't a HUGE ribeye like you would expect, they served it sliced so it is a manageable portion, which I appreciated. The meat was a LITTLE chewy but still had great flavor.   All in all, we can't wait to come back! The restaurant itself has 4 different small rooms. I would say the biggest party size for a night out with friends would be 10 (we took up most of their main room) and definitely make a reservation. It makes a great date night spot and is very romantic. They have fresh cocktails and a lovely wine list as well. The service was friendly and the server was extremely passionate about FnB and the magic behind their food.

photos.caption: Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. DELICIOUS potatoes served cold
Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. Super yummy pasta with potato chips on top!
Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. Sliced Ribeye over wheatberries with peppers + fennel... amazing flavor!

INhoIQ9AJ79zum7lmvz0tQ.text: The place itself is a little dated and could use a renovation. However, the food was INCREDIBLE! It was right up our alley.  We ordered from the Spring 2019 menu:  Salad w/ Strawberries + Rhubarb. Falafel w/ Stewed Chickpeas, Green Garlic Tahini + Fermented Hot Sauce. Summer Squash w/ Provolone + Salsa Verde. (This was so bomb!) Spring Pasta w/ Fava + Romano Beans.  Last, but definitely not least:  Butter Toasted Cornbread w/ Strawberries + Strawberry Buttermilk Ice Cream. (OMG!!!!!!!!! Sooo GOOD!!)  We shall surely return!

Eib12Zo_TW7Qod4jg-K3Vw.text: I have been to FnB about half a dozen times with my first visit being in 2013. I have not been reviewing on Yelp often back then, so this is actually my first review for this restaurant and my rating is strictly based on my most recent visit in January.  Had I rated FnB back in 2013-2015, I would've given them 5 stars hands down! (See photos from back then in my photos. Nice and bright ones are from back then and the dark and dreary ones are from the recent visit which reflects the ratings as well coincidentally...) Unfortunately, my recent visit was not so good, hence the 2 stars.  I brought my friends who are new in town to introduce them to a great farm to table restaurant concept. Starting with the first dish we were disappointed and I had to send it back.    What we ordered: -Chicken fried chicken livers, green goddess dressing: right away I tasted that it was too bitter.  We realize that it was the batter that was bitter and the liver itself was underseasoned making it inedible. I sent it back. -chilled octopus, pickled caper leaves, oca, pink grapefruit, lemon mayo: this dish was pretty good. Octopus cooked to perfection. Refreshing and tasty dish. -creekstone farms ribeye, grilled potatoes, dried tomato chermoula, baby kale: the ribeye was ok, but the potatoes were amazing. Overall a good dish. -Risotto, rock shrimp, meyer lemon, snap peas, i'itoi onion, basil: this one was favorite out of the entire dinner. Risotto was perfectly cooked, the flavor was spot on. -macau style African chicken, rice, peppers, greens, peanuts. What makes it macau style and what African? Was there harissa in there somewhere? I don't taste either distinctive flavors but the chicken was tender. :D - bottle of 2016 Rune Grenache wine. First time trying a bottle of AZ wine and I was pleasantly surprised. Restaurant price of $64 per bottle tho? I'm not sure I'd order again.  -dessert - persimmon cake, pomegranate seeds, vanilla ice cream. We were excited about the persimmon cake and fully expected persimmon flavor to come thru...thoroughly disappointed. The cake was flavorless and didn't do much for any of us.   The overall food experience was about 3 and the service was 1. Total bill was $235 plus tip. Had the food been great, the price isn't bad. However, with mediocre food and service, I'd rather spend a little more and go somewhere else.   Our reservation was at 6:30, we got our food at around 7:15 pm and we were finished by 8:45. We were having a good conversation and catching up with friends. At 9 pm, the host comes by and apologized and asked us to leave because they have to get the table ready for the next party. It was a 4 top and I didn't see anyone waiting or standing there! She did offer to move us to another area, but I didn't see any other area that was free. This is the first time I've ever gotten kicked out of a restaurant!! Wow. How embarrassing for me in front of my friends and I had to apologize to them for bringing them here. Never again.

photos.caption: Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. Gourmet grilled cheese if you will.  Hot pressed buns, aged cheese, whole grain mustard, and ramps.  Served with house made pickles.  (2015)

Photo of FnB - Scottsdale, AZ, United States. Crispy breaded chicken cutlet, bianco tomatoes, mozzarella, parmesan, arugula, karolyn’s ricotta.  Chicken was crispy outside, juicy inside.

XckkXhBfLh74lOPpWfnpGQ.text: Stayed out at the Boulders & wandered in to old town for a meal. What a delight! Fabulous food and a great view of the cooking over a mesquite bed of coals on a grill. Great beet salad ,lamb tenderloin fit for a king. Regional ingredients made for an outstanding meal. Planning on a return visit. Also, one of the few non-over-airconditioned places we visited-a plus.

BiYnOBLGx6ObceWrW68S9Q.text: Amazing food!  Amazing service!  Only drawback is the place is quite small.  However, the quality of the food and the service more than makes up for the size... What a gem!

Vxyw7Sr8hIa27Vpg9st8Bg.text: It seems that success has gone to the head of this fine establishment. I can't review the restaurant currently because I could not get seated at the bar as a walk in, which was a common occurrence in the old location. I tried twice--there was one open seat when I arrived and when I checked back a few minutes later. I was told that all the seats at the bar and at tables were spoken for over the entire evening, though I asked if this was True for late dinner and was told yes. I went elsewhere but called later to ask if they took reservations for the bar and was told that those seats were reserved for walk-ins! This is a different establishment than the one that received all the awards and accolades. Since I am in Scottsdale only once or twice a year, there will be no repercussions for the restaurant but I wanted others to know these circumstances for their reference.

iOZLgKUDQBOMCEC28XZYgw.text: Even though it took us 2 hours to get seated (no fault of FnB, Joel L NEEDED to sit by the window!), I had an awesome time here last night. See, I get teased a lot for never leaving CenPho.  In fact, Lara asked me "Are you ever allowed to get out?" so I knew it was time to finally check this place out. I'd been in touch with Pavle for a couple days.  He's adorable!!  Had to meet him. They have late night eats, which is $10 plates after 10pm.  Score!!!  They had two choices last night: brisket and chilaquiles for the vegetarians.  Once we were seated, it only took about 10 minutes to get our food.  We were served a small veggie platter to tide us over.  There were these little garlic pickles that were to die for!  Kirti even asked for a little extra of these and they were devoured instantly. The place was PACKED.  They were out of the brisket, but seemed to come up with two servings for my dining companions. I had the chilaquiles.  Holy cripes!  They were delicious and came with an egg on top.  I loooooooooooooove eggs.  So much so that I want to marry an egg.  Not Humpty Dumpty, because I'm little, but maybe he has a little cousin or something. Anyway, the service was unbelievable.  They made me some lime drink concoction (non-alcoholic).  I had 3 of them!  Chunks of lime, lots of ice.  Sooooo delicious, especially for a warm summer night. Sitting by the window was the BEST.  Watching the drunk Scottsdale girls stumbling around Old Town made the wait worthwhile.  Watching them park?  Priceless. I ran into a lot of CenPho Escapees there, too.  What does this mean?  That it's ok to venture to Old Town, but *only* for FnB. Thank you so much, Pavle, for an amazing night.  And thanks to my friends, for making me feel guilt-free about leaving my 'hood.

sDV_dBAZbqCNgY208b6g8A.text: The reviews of FnB seem to fall into two categories, the majority that rave about the place and those don't see what people are raving about.  I have to say, I'm in the minority.  I just don't get what people love about FnB.  The menu is strange in that there are about 15 "sides" and apps, but only 4 entres.  My wife and I ordered the cheese plate, the shishitos, the eggplant, the pasta and the chicken.  The three sides/apps came all at once to the small table, leaving us a little crowded and feeling  rushed.  The cheese plate featured a  sliver of cheese, much too much charred nut bread, some dates, some nectarine slices, some pecans, and an apricot preparation.  It was all fine, but not at all interesting or nicely presented.  The shishitos and the eggplant were both pretty bland except for the padron peppers in the eggplant dish.  The pasta and the chicken were both uninteresting and bland.  All evening I found myself looking for a salt shaker.  My wife eventually asked for some crushed red pepper for the pasta.  Didn't try desert or coffee.  Nothing was very bad, but nothing was very good either.  At present, FnB does not have a liquor license so it's BYOB.  There is a $15 corkage fee.  It seems fairly high to me.  The last time I brought my own bottle was several years ago at Quiessence.  I don't remember a corkage fee there at all.  The fee is waived if you bring Arizona wine.  I'm all for eating locally produced foods, but seriously, Arizona wine!?!  The tile floor (left over from Seasaw) is very nice.

aZZEAh6bPUXHZfyj0jB79A.text: My boyfriend an I went to FnB almost a year and a half ago ( I know and its taken me this long to review!), but I can still remember the sights, aromas, and good company we enjoyed there. We were in Scottsdale for only five days, and we dined at FnB two of those five nights. The food is honest and simple yet amazingly delicious, we ordered just about everything on the menu between the two nights and were satisfied with all of the dishes. Our waiter was very knowledgeable and made great recommendations on wine. I highly recommend this restaurant.

cLUOFjrALhevkivcqmmWig.text: Definitely a gem in old town; the food is great. You won't be disappointed!

5qYyEMGXJstKUgMpUAxRWw.text: my favorite restaurant in the valley, no questions asked. everything is so carefully prepared, lovingly delivered to your table and so delicious. you can't go wrong, really. eat here. eat everything, eat it all. chef charlene badman has a way with vegetables. it's really pure magic. all my meat-eating companions have nothing but good things to say.   go here. you won't be disappointed.

9-uXGSd2A0UAzpMtRapPLg.text: Recommended by the concierge at the Hotel Valley Ho, our group of 6 ventured over not knowing what to expect. I can honestly say that this is probably in my top 3 best restaurant experiences of my entire life. Pavle was our server and had incredible energy and passion about the menu items. Describing in detail many of the menu items, we decided to ask him, quite simply, "just bring us food" and the journey began. Pavle brought us small plates and entrees, vegetarian dishes and meat dishes. Interesting ingredients, all fresh and local and presented beautifully to our table in perfect time. Every bite was an adventure and created conversation. Never did we feel rushed and we all couldn't stop raving about all the different dishes we tried. Highlights for me included the turkish lamb dumplings and the falafel with delfino cilantro. We all left with a big smile on our faces and feeling full, but not overally full. I cannot wait to come back to Scottsdale and try the next FNB selections. A most unique and memorable dining experience.

tYNQo95Z2JPKu9wpCJETag.text: 7.30pm dinner at the bar with my son.  I started with the Rock shrimp which were lightly fried in a delicious batter with an equally good dipping sauce. A little too much for my appetizer but my son helped finish them off.  He opted for the cheese which was unusually good for an American cheese. I ordered the Rabbit dish for my entree. It was wonderfully put together with homemade pasta, a variety of vegetables and seasoned to perfection.  Absolutely delicious! It was a very ample portion and after the shrimp proved too much for me to finish.  My son had the rib eye steak which was cooked perfectly and very tasty. I also ordered a side of roast vegetables which was way too much food.  Having said that, we couldn't resist the yummy looking sweets! I opted for the grapefruit cake and my son, being a chocolate lover went for the chocolate cake.  Unfortunately this is where I think the quality slipped a little. Although both desserts were very tasty, if eaten without the creamy topping the cake in both was on the dry side. I understand that they were both meant to be eaten as a whole with their respective toppings but the cake part shouldn't have been dry.   That said the whole experience was extremely enjoyable and I would absolutely return.

a8WWT6Io1b8MLzwHT54Img.text: The broccoli is to die for!  The owner and chef love their food and are willing take you on a food journey with each bite.  There is a large selection of Arizona wines, but not much else.  Sitting around the kitchen is the best place to be to watch the chef at work.

LEWywAtGjGusZVlTsF7pZQ.text: Can't help but jump myself onto the FnB wagon train. Have experienced many wonderful meals here.    I don't know what they do to the chicken but it is simply fabulous. Even simple grilled broccoli is so tasty that I actually dream about it despite my carnivorous tendencies.  Late nights on Friday and Saturday are terrific deals and a lot of fun from the kitchen.  The other night I  had the best darn pho I have ever had in Phoenix.

hTgqPkmk3Dp7t2YpifVi4A.text: the menu always changes, so i can't make any recommendations, but everything here was delicious and the waitstaff was very prompt and polite. they had a great wine list and some interesting sounding cocktails too.

C0flcQmozBjL5lO-r7NOSQ.text: I took my wife last Friday night to celebrate our 22nd anniversary and had a fabulous evening! Pavle made us feel like family and the food was delicious and unique. The Pinot Noir we had was so good we joined the wineries mailing list. Highly Recommend!

7uDjDDKofkbCNk_Ler02vg.text: Delicious.  Attentive and courteous service, quaint location, and did I mention - delicious???  Thus far I've only been here for a Javelina Leap wine dinner, and normally I'd reserve judgement until I'd had a meal or two off the menu.  In this the deliciousness factor wins out and I'm going with 5 stars.  The dishes here are a perfect example of completely unexpected combinations of ingredients blending harmoniously to achieve...well... deliciousness.

2ZN4Ir7QM-jNg8ouaJi9Bw.text: FnB is that rare restaurant that poses the most difficult of all reviewer dilemmas.  Try to keep it a secret, hoping to always get a last-minute table,  or, let the world know, serving the greater good of diners everywhere. Well, being an altruistic person -   I ate dinner at FnB Friday night, my 4th time. Fresh, local ingredients. Inventive but accessible recipes.  Perfect execution.  Lovely service.  I've eaten my way through most of the menu and can't find fault with a single item.  Of particular note, the panna cotta with mulberries and kumquats is sublime.  Don't even think of sharing it.  This dish is everything a dessert should be.  A little bit of heaven.  Reserve well ahead of time and sit at the bar if you can, and watch the food being prepared.    Try a vegetable that you don't think you like - FnB will change your mind.

f08DJ5wR2Ztpn87BS8zy4g.text: Love, love, love! Service is always fabulous and every dish has been perfect. The local cheese plate and AZ wine selections are amazing. I think between the 5 of us we have had everything on the menu, and it was all delicious. This is my fave place in the country right now. Can't wait to go back over the holidays!

wqD-Xz5rWKJDO8r4oh5k9g.text: It was everything I thought it would be. Fresh seasonal ingredients executed with an above-average degree of skill.  The service was good but I got tired of hearing about the origin and history of every ingredient. Nothing really knocked my socks off so four stars is all.

LMimzcic60xP6c6eloXyZQ.text: When one finds someone/something that inspires loyalty, it is a beautiful thing!  Peggy and I dined at the new location of FnB this evening, and our loyalty to the duo of Pavle Milic and Charlene Badman was once again royally rewarded. Spicy broccoli with tangerine aioli and pistachio, and Peg had the hand-pulled mozzarella and leeks gribiche to start the evening.  Actually, seeing Pavle and Charlene began the evening, so things were never in question. I had the roast chicken, which would seem to be a very uninspired dish in most venues. The addition of spaetzle, spigarelllo and pan jus didn't allow that to happen. Peg had the corvina (read: white seabass) with a pomegranate-persimmon, get-your-freekah-on, and Meyer lemon chermoula. Passing the always wonderful butterscotch pudding (gotten probably 80% of the time) we opted for a kumquat lemon verbina creme brulee. Aside from the technical wizardry that Charlene produces, the new place (nee Baratin) had a very comfortable vibe. The rooms and decor are inviting, and it is hard to believe that not a beat was skipped. We told both Pavle and Charlene that we would be happily content with 50% of them on opening night.....we got 100%....as always!  Dr. B

iU6C-EkKVGI45f0BctPnPQ.text: Was just in Scottsdale two weeks ago. wanted to try a new place. I was very impressed. The food was awesome and the waiter knew his stuff. Will come here again when I am in town...

MRV8R7HIyS6b8id-Lbiy7A.text: Great change of pace from the usual fare! The the Falafel with Tahini app is fantastic!

De4tsdg-LIf8xq8yOhpN4A.text: Dissappointing Experience.  Based on the reviews (and the bill), we expected a lot more.  Food was fine, but not exceptional.  Did not like the "butterscotch" pudding dessert - was not sweet nor did it taste anything like butterscotch.  We did notify the waitress about this, and she did take it off the bill (after exclaiming that no one had ever complained about it before!).  Servers were very casual in appearance and personality - not what one would expect at a resturant where entres are $40.  We also had poor service - seemed like no one waiter was assigned to our table - we had to flag down various people for service.  Additionally the tables and chairs were very close together.  All in all, it was much more casual atmosphere than expected based on reviews.  There are so many great resturants in Scottsdale; unfortunately this was not one of them!

3DX3iCMal02QCPveeF1XfQ.text: While researching restaurants for our visit from Chicago, I was most excited to try FnB.  Reviews highlighted its focus on local ingredients to make award-winning food, and we were not disappointed.  We were also lucky enough to have co-owner Pavle Milic as our host (the word "waiter" falls horribly short in describing his role in our dining experience), and he made us feel so welcomed.  The food was fantastic!  We started off with the leeks and the falafel, which were both delicious.  Husband had the grouper, which was very delicately seasoned, bringing out the simple flavor of the fish.  I had the roast jidori chicken, which was crispy on the outside and juicy inside.  Definitely try the wines, which are also all local to Arizona.  We ate a lot of good food on this trip, but FnB was definitely the highlight!

sDq22BliudYmUPAV-ne-xQ.text: There's nothing bad I can say about our experience at FnB.  The drinks, food, staff, atmosphere- all excellent.    I tried two of the cocktails from the menu- the Milano and the Spring Sundowner.  The Milano was a very flavorful drink that was somewhat bitter, but after a few sips my tastebuds became acquainted to the flavor and I happily guzzled the rest of it.  The Spring Sundowner, however, was DELICIOUS from the first sip to the last.  It was so light and refreshing and delicately sweet.  I'd go out of my way just to sit and sip one of these cocktails.  We had the leeks, mozzarella breadcrumbs and egg.  I'm glad we followed the crowd and tried this before leeks go out of season!  Every bite was delicious with a perfect balance of texture- the tender, smooth leeks with the gooey mozzarella and egg, plus a little bit of crunch from the breadcrumbs.
